414 REVIEW OF ECONOMIC STUDIES

The advantages of experimental research, when adapted to the needs of economics,
are striking. Compared to traditional empirical research in economics the experimenter
has considerable control over the design of the markets within which his economic agents
operate, and he can exclude some influences from which he wishes to abstract while con-
centrating on others he wishes to study. Anyone questioning results within the experi-
mental framework is able to replicate an experiment performed by someone else and
analyze entirely new and independent data. On the other hand, the world of the experi-
menter is artificial and of his own design; so the extent to which experimental results
may be taken as a clue to behaviour in real life markets is uncertain.

The two conclusions on oligopolistic behaviour which emerge from these studies are:
the Cournot solution characterizes behaviour in incomplete information situations, and,
under complete information, a subject is more cooperative, the more cooperative is his
rival. It is not obvious whether these conclusions will obtain under more intensive examin-
ation, or how more comprehensive experiments will find them modified; however, they
are interesting results and suggestive of what might be done experimentally.

University of Rochester J. W. FRIEDMAN

Such a sensitivity test is in some sense a type of validation of the curves drawn, but
more direct validations could be proposed. The indifference curves obtained could be
used to predict choices among commodities not lying on one of these curves. This could
be done by simple extrapolation or interpolation. Another possible attempt at validation
could be performed if a constant marginal utility of a common commodity could be
assumed and two sets of indifference curves would be used to predict the third set, as
Thurstone attempted to do.

A more interesting test would be to form pairs of individuals and put them together
in a barter situation with some fixed amount of two commodities and allow them to leave
with whatever division they agree upon. By putting their indifference curves together
into an Edgeworth box one could see how close they come to the contract curve. That is,
one would predict that in a one-shot situation they would form a division on the contract
curve and the actual division would form a test of the accuracy of the individual in-
difference curves. Alternatively, they could be started on the contract curve and any
movement away would be noted and would be evidence of the lack of validity of the
indifference curves.

Another attempt to validate the indifference curves by direct prediction would be to
make the appropriate assumptions to get numerical utilities and then these could be used
to predict choices. Any discrepancy though could be attributed to either poor indifference
curves or the invalidity of the assumptions made. "This topic will be explored in some
depth in a forthcoming paper (MacCrimmon and Toda [8]).

Most of the discussion above is directed to determination of indifference curves in
situations that an experimenter constructs. However, we might wonder whether these
procedures can be used in real world choice situations where preferences could be reflected
by indifference curves, for example, the bombs and bombers trade-off of Hitch and McKean.
It should be obvious that the emphasis on training, reflection, and checks on consistency
could be part of any consideration of preferences. Also, the complexity reduction tech-
niques based on admissibility can easily be used. This, then, only leaves the question of
whether the payoff part of the method is useful in real world choices. Note that as we
use it in experiments it is particularly effective because the subject will actually receive a
commodity bundle based on his positioning of the indifference curve. Clearly there are
many situations, not only bombs and bombers, in which we are not prepared to give the
individual one of the commodity bundles. This leads to the question of whether the payoff
part of the method is of any use when applied hypothetically—for example, ** suppose
after you draw the indifference curve we randomly select a combination of bombs and
bombers, if it is in your accept region we will give you that combination, if it is in your
reject region you get the reference bundle." Whether such hypothetical payoffs are
effective is an empirical matter, but in any case it is probably as good as any other pro-
cedure in these contexts. Since all important decisions involve a representation of prefer-
ences in some form or other, it would be useful to explore the possibilities of applying these
experimentally based procedures in real world choice situations.

APPENDIX

Procedures

Subjects were male undergraduates recruited ** to earn money in a research project "
at the University of Virginia. From 8 to 12 subjects participated in each of seven sessions.
All of the matched SRP class, joint cooperation experiments took place over a period of
eight days, but the others were as much as a year apart. Each session lasted from one to
two and one-half hours. An attempt to assign subjects randomly to sessions was only
modified slightly by occasional conflicts in subject's schedules. In each session, the SRP
test was carried out first; then subjects read instructions explaining the number and letter
choice matrix-game. They were situated so that none could see another's work space,
payoff tables, decisions, or earnings.

Thirty-six subjects were formed into subject-pairs from the same SRP class for the
joint cooperation experiment. To minimize the learning that might occur, similar (letter
and number choice) games were played first, before Payoff Tables IV and V were used
for the joint cooperation experiment. Assignments of subjects to pairs were made
randomly for the preliminary games, and fifteen of these pairs involved differential SRP
score classes, which were used in the examination of differential earnings within pairs.
Twelve other differential SRP class pairs were observed at other sessions solely for this
purpose. A total of 60 subjects participated in the experiments.

When the joint cooperation experiment was begun subjects were told that the other
persons with whom they were matched would definitely be different than in the preliminary
game. Subject pairs were then drawn from identical risk classes. Half of the subject-
pairs within each SRP class started the experiment in Payoff Table IV, the other half in
V. About midway in the joint cooperation experiment, payoff tables were changed from

484 REVIEW OF ECONOMIC STUDIES

As in any experiment, the results have been influenced by the structure of the environ-
ment established by the experimenters. For example, the disparity in profit performances
would probably not have been so great had there been strong penalities for very bad
results as well as rewards for very good performances. Subjects might also have been
induced to move more rapidly toward the optimal rule by being supplied regularly with
comparative data on the cumulative profit being amassed by the computer and effectively
exhorted not to fall behind or fall any further behind. But the fact remains that even
when the structure of a simple economic problem is completely specified and there is
some incentive to make good decisions, there is no guarantee that a decision maker will
tend toward a theoretically optimal rule.

This illustrates one kind of contribution that experimental economics can make.
Experiments based on theoretical models can draw to our attention matters of concern
that might otherwise be overlooked if one did not have to worry about specifying the
structure of the entire environment and could assume precisely how people will behave in
any given situation.

496 REVIEW OF ECONOMIC STUDIES

In addition, our data amplify and expand the work of Siegel and Fouraker [9] on
the role of personality variables as determinants of bargaining behaviour. We have noted
that the RTP of a bargainer has a significant impact on his bargaining process itself as
well as on the outcomes consequent to this process. "These effects of RTP seem to be
significantly moderated by the structural context within which bargaining occurs; namely,
the environment of information, communication and power.

Viewed from an additional perspective, bargaining as a theoretical construct and
bargaining behaviour as an empirical focus play an important role in organizational
behaviour and organizational theory. In this regard, the research reported in this paper
can be viewed as relevant to several current issues in organizational behaviour and theory.
First, much of the recent work by Homans [6], Adams [1] and Weick [10] has indicated
the powerful role that the equity of a reward plays in influencing attitudes and performance
in organized settings. The role of differential attitudinal and behavioural results in a
bargaining task is central to this stream of work. Our results on the differential affect
toward the bargaining task and toward earnings generated by the power and information
variables generally support this stream of research and add to the task generality of
previous results. Second, an important issue in organizational behaviour and organiza-
tional theory is the relative value to be attached to increments in information available to
bargainers in an organizational setting. Our results, generated through experimentally
varying the amount of information available to a bargainer regarding the possible monetary
payoffs to his opponent associated with any given bargaining contract, are relevant to this
theme. Our data support the suggestion in the literature that under specified bargaining
conditions information regarding a counterpart's payoffs may possess negative value.
Third, the role of personal characteristics in determining the bargaining behaviour of a
triad is a critical area for research in organizational behaviour. We view the risk-taking
propensity of the participants as particularly relevant to understanding their behaviour on
bargaining tasks. Our results indicate that there are significant individual differences in
the manner in which high and low risk-takers handle information, power and communica-
tion in a competitive setting. Fourth, the role of differential power associated with hier-
archical status in determining bargaining processes and results is crucial to our under-
standing of behaviour in organizations. Our results indicate that possessing a terminal
position in a bargaining exchange (e.g. who has the last offer in a superior-subordinate
negotiation regarding salary, duties, discipline, etc.) does generate significant differences
in bargaining processes and results. .Fifthly, the literature of administration and, more
recently, organizational behaviour has been concerned with the behavioural and affective
consequences of the degree to which communication channels are ** open ", both vertically
and laterally, in an organization. Our experimental variations of the availability of
communication are relevant to the issue of whether communication necessarily increases
the profitability and/or the perceptions of satisfaction associated with bargaining.

CONCLUSION

We feel that laboratory simulation of organizational processes of the type described
in this paper is a useful but certainly not exclusive strategy for investigating bargaining
behaviour in a triad relationship. It does, however, seem particularly appropriate at
our present state of knowledge in specifying the determinants of bargaining behaviour
and their interrelationships. Based upon the findings reported here, our research is
moving in two directions; (1) the investigation of the determinants of bargaining in an
asymmetric bargaining triad and (2) the experimental control of bidding behaviour and
the contents of written communications in order to investigate the effects of competitive
vs. cooperative bargaining strategies.

they are not, there will be portfolio adjustments, possibly accompanied by subsequent

These results are contrary to the analysis of Mundell and others which seems to imply
a reverse chain of causal relations, with asset equilibrium requiring levels of income
consistent with the existing money stocks—a situation which would require given levels
of exports relative to imports and, hence, a given exchange rate. The capital flow is then
Whatever is necessary to make up the difference between exports and imports. Mundell's
analysis, and the Keynesian foreign-trade multiplier models from which much of the
contemporary theory is derived, assume that the public is willing to hold any amount of
capital assets relative to money stock, but only a given stock of money in relation to income
at each interest rate. This cannot be so, since the demand for money is a function of
wealth and is therefore related to the amount of assets owned.

While the currently used approach contains fundamental theoretical deficiencies, the
conclusions as to the conditions under which monetary policy will be effective under fixed
and flexible exchange rate are essentially correct (although the analysis, by confusing
stocks and flows, tends to focus attention on the level of the money stock rather than on
its rate of change as the major policy instrument). In the case of fiscal policy, however,
our analysis indicates the fallacy of Mundell's conclusion that fiscal policy is ineffective
under a flexible exchange rate; rather, fiscal policy will be effective in both the short and
the long run under both fixed and flexible exchange rate systems. In the short run, fiscal
policy will be less effective in increasing employment under a fixed exchange rate than under
a flexible one; but in the long run it will be more effective under a flexible exchange rate.

III. CONCLUSION

We have shown that it is possible to construct a meaningful market model without
assuming that the decision maker possesses information which in most cases he does not
in fact have. The marginal-cost-plus policy adopted in this approach is consistent with
the desire to maximize profit, and we have shown that the stability of the model can be
ensured with a set of conditions that are not unduly restrictive. Moreover, the model
yields a number of hypotheses concerning the effects of changes in a shift parameter;
while we analyzed only the effects of a tax parameter, the results suggest that the effects of
other parameter changes will be just as determinate. Finally, one result on which we did
not dwell in the text may be stated here as a concluding comment. Since the choices
made by each firm under the rules specified in this paper are different from those which
the firm would make if it had full information about its demand function, and since under
the latter circumstances the profit of each firm would be less than what it could earn under
a cartel arrangement, it follows that the actual level of profit earned under conditions of
lack of information may be higher than that earned under full information. Thus,
ignorance is not necessarily the root of all evil.

Conclusion

In this section I have used two alternative methods to estimate the period of the
cycles likely to be generated by Goodwin's model of cyclical growth. Both methods show
that with reasonable values of the parameters, the period is considerably longer than the
4 or 5 years of the typical recent trade cycle. A cycle with this period is only likely to be
generated if all profits are saved, if the capital-output ratio is very low (less than 2), and
real wages respond very strongly to a fall in unemployment. In fact the model as it stands
may be better suited to explaining the 16-22 year '*' Kuznets " cycle than the postwar
trade cycle.

4. CONCLUDING COMMENTS

In this paper I have discussed three quite different models of economic growth and
tried to show that in each case examination of the timescale provides useful information
about their behaviour. This is not altogether surprising, since some kind of time dimension
is implicit or explicit in our thinking about any real economy; and we should expect the
timescale of these models to be important for understanding their relationship to the real
world.

In the course of the paper I have made considerable use of numerical methods of
analysis, and in particular of numerical methods to solve differential equations which
could not be solved analytically. This technique seems to have been relatively little used
in recent economic literature, although similar methods were used in the 1950's to analyze
the behaviour of trade cycle models. While such numerical methods cannot yield results
of the strength which economists have come to expect, I hope that the present paper has
demonstrated that this capital-intensive approach can have considerable value.

4. CONCLUSION

In his discussion of liquidity preference and portfolio choice as behaviour towards
risk, Tobin has been careful to emphasize that the mean-variance analysis must be regarded
as an approximation (e.g., Tobin [17], pp. 12-14). This paper has shown that even his
rather plausible simplifying assumption that the investor's subjective probability distribu-
tion has only two parameters is insufficient for deriving the indifference curve convexity
properties that facilitate the analysis of investor behaviour. Moreover, if there is more
than one asset, an analysis in terms of only mean and variance is not strictly possible unless
utility functions are assumed quadratic or probability distributions are severely restricted.

But the inability to obtain unambiguous a priori conclusions about liquidity preference
or portfolio choice behaviour does not diminish Tobin's contribution in emphasisizing
the importance of analyzing this behaviour as optimization under uncertainty. Rather
it emphasizes the need to develop empirical research in this direction.

The Measurement of Utility '

INTRODUCTION

In this paper we show how the utility levels attained by a consumer may be measured
exactly under idealized conditions. These conditions include knowledge of the trajectories
of prices, income, and quantities, and of the numerical magnitudes of certain elasticities.
The approach taken provides a ranking for all consumption vectors on the trajectory.

An analytical expression is given, showing the effects on the marginal utility of income
of changes in income and in relative prices. These effects depend on the income elasticities
of commodities and on the income elasticity of the marginal utility of income. A link
is thus provided between a number of concepts and parameters of consumer theory.

The result also lends itself to empirical application. Estimates of the demand
elasticities are available from many econometric studies. The less well known elasticity
of the marginal utility of income plays a role in intertemporal utility maximization. Follow-
ing Samuelson we show how it may be estimated from data on total consumption
expenditures over time.

The conditions for leaving a fixed capital out of the aggregate were given in [2,
pp. 274-282] for the case in which all capitals are fixed; we have referred to them above.
In the present case, similarly strong conditions are involved and there seems no point in
going into them in detail. It will suffice to say two things about them in the present context.

First, the amount of some labour employed by one firm and not by another may as
well be considered as a parameter of that firm's production function when dealing with
the Leontief conditions relative to the labours employed by both. This means that those
conditions (essentially (3.8) and (3.9) with appropriate notational changes) must hold
for all values of such labour employment. Even if the firm's production function was
homogeneous of degree one in all employed factors it will not generally be so in the factors
other than the special labour type in question, so it will not be possible to solve the Leontief
conditions with respect to the labours employed in common as was done in the proof of
Theorem 4.1. Indeed, those conditions can perfectly well fail to be satisfied for a given
firm no matter what the other firm's technology looks like.!

A similar statement holds even more forcefully when dealing with the Leontief condi-
tions relative to the labour type in question itself. Here the existence of a total capital
aggregate requires that the production function of the firm which employs that labour
satisfy a special condition ensuring that the direct effects of an increase in the amount
of the labour in question on the marginal product of fixed capital be exactly offset by the
indirect effects of the reallocation of the other movable factors.? Such conditions are very
strong.

Thus, it is clearly most unlikely that the nonemployment of a particular labour type
by a particular firm and hence the nonequalization of that labour type's marginal products
makes total capital aggregation any easier. Closed-form results for this particular aspect
of the problem are very hard to come by, however.

by several authors. These authors have used utility functions of various forms. The results

1. INTRODUCTION

An explanation of the rise and fall of firms' output levels is not sufficient to account
for the changes in the quantity produced by an entire industry, since these will often be
accompanied by changes in the number of firms. It seems plausible that the factors govern-
ing the creation or annihilation of a firm are somewhat different from the factors which
govern the adjustment of an existing firm's output level to changes in demand or cost
conditions. The latter type of adjustment depends on demand and cost functions and
perhaps on some assumptions about the behaviour of competing firms as in the Cournot
model; the former type of adjustment may also depend on the magnitude of the reward
that can be expected upon entry into the industry.

The treatment of the problem of entry and exit is seldom formalized. The typical
argument in the case of perfect competition is as follows: if firms in the industry are making
profits in excess of normal profit, new entrepreneurs will be induced to enter the industry.
Their entry shifts the industry supply curve to the right and the market price falls. Each
firm in the industry then reduces its output and profits fall. The process continues until
profit in excess of normal profit becomes zero. Similarly, if losses are being incurred
some entrepreneurs leave the industry, the aggregate supply is reduced, market price rises
and profits rise to zero. The equilibrium number of firms is determined by the condition
that profit equal zero ([3, pp. 96-8, 192-5].

The analysis of entry and exit will rest on several assumptions which are as follows:

(1) In the absence of a complete specification of the cost functions of potential firms
not yet producing, it will be assumed that all firms, actual or potential, are identical with
respect to costs.

be assumed that the rate of change in the number of firms over time can be suitably
analyzed by means of difference or differential equations, even in those cases in which the
solution to these equations indicates that at some particular time the number of firms is

V. CONCLUDING REMARKS

In an a-temporal world of a certain class it is easy to show that every equilibrium is
efficient. In situations where the future extends indefinitely, this is not always the case
[9]. In particular it is important to distinguish between two views of competitive equili-
brium: there is the situation where producers are in equilibrium from moment to moment—
this is the case of the present paper. However if we trace the economy forward far enough
this equilibrium may cease to be possible or efficient, although there may be no way of
discovering this in finite time. On the other hand we could think of producers as being
in equilibrium also in the sense that at each : the present value of their assets is maximized
(if such a maximum exists). The economy then behaves as one which had infinitely many
future markets. In such a world the actual path chosen by the economy will be Pareto-
efficient, and it will be quite different from the economy investitated here.

Now it is certainly possible for the paths generated by the present construction to be
Pareto-inefficient for a long enough horizon [8]. I conclude from this that if the world
behaves in this manner, the way for the economy to be made to behave efficiently is for
someone to * aim " it at a target. Thus there may be, given K(0), a unique choice of
Y(0), which if now made, will lead the economy along its expectation fulfilling path to the
steady state. [If indeed the motion were always ** catenary " we could assert that there
will be one such choice of Y(0)—as it is, there may be several.] In that case, if a planning
board announced the appropriate rate of change in relative capital goods prices, producers
ought to expect at ? — 0, the economy thereafter will seek the steady state. In any case what
our idealization shows is, that even if we assume all the frictions, which stop say, the
equalization of own rates, at all ? away, the invisible hand will generally need a visible one
to guide it. To say that this is due to the absence of an infinity of futures markets, is
correct but not consoling.

The paradoxical fact is that if we do not make such very strong demands on the invisible
hand at all moments of time it may perform in some sense * better " in the long run.
Thus for instance if we suppose producers to expect current prices to persist forever even
when the steady state has been perturbed, but retain all our other assumptions, then Mori-
shima has shown [5] that the economy will seek the steady state. Thus while at all moments
the economy is making mistakes they are never the big ones it is capable of in the ** correct
expectation " case. This suggests that it may well be that by idealizing as much as we have
done, we have not only created some artificial problems, but we are prevented from analyz-
ing the róle of one of the most important features of a decentralized and unguided economy
namely that at most times economic agents find that their decisions with consequences for
the future, were not the appropriate ones. There is also the plain fact that not all agents
have the same expectations as to the future values of the same variable, and of course that
these expectations are uncertain. It may well be that it is precisely such ** frictional aspects "
of the world we live in which prevent it going disastrously ** off the rails ", but no one
really knows.

London School of Economics. F. H. HAHN.

It cannot be overemphasized that the choice here need not be the same as or depend on
the choice of concept of interest referred to above. The question of choosing the appro-
priate form for estimation has to do with a correct description, or specification, of the
structure that generated the observations. For an exogenous output industry one would use
a demand curve with output as an independent variable, whereas for profit maximizing
firms one would use ratios of factors to product prices only. Similarly, if for some reason
the cost or profit of the firms are predetermined then one should estimate demand functions
with cost or profit respectively as independent variables.

The foregoing considerations apply also to the choice between short and long run
measures. Since all observations can be considered, apart from random variations, as
observations of short run equilibrium, one should be estimating short run demand functions
where the fixed factors and not their prices enter [10, 11]. This is simply a question of
corrrect specification and has nothing to do with the desired measure of substitution or
with the form of the production function.

There is another aspect to the choice of ES, that of generating production functions.
As has been pointed out above, there is no direct relationship between the concept one
wants to use and the algebraic form for the production function. Nevertheless there are
no clear guide lines for selecting functions and if one has to depend on empirical analysis
there is no harm in generating functions under the assumptions that some ES are constant
and to let the data determine their relevance. Even under this principle, we still face some
difficulties which are mainly related to the two factor two price ES. As has been shown
above, in general these measures are not independent of the directions in which the relevant
prices change. Fixing the ES for one directional change in prices has no economic
justification. Furthermore, concentrating on one ES of a pair with respect to own prices
still leaves the others unspecified. These two remarks are not independent and not trivial
in nature. They are related to the fact that the general theory of the economic unit, be it
consumer or a firm, cannot be reformulated in terms of two variable two price ES. So
at best, one takes a partial view, but imposes a great deal, when requiring the production
function to satisfy some conditions on one differential equation.

It is a different matter with the one price one factor measures. As we have seen,
these are not necessarily pure measures of substitution. However, they are directly related
to the Hessian matrix, which is the canonical form of the underlying structure. The other
measures impose constraints on various combinations of the elements of such a Hessian
matrix. But there are many more combinations of such elements than elements them-
selves, hence it should be more efficient to try to deal with these elements directly rather
than through ES.

VI. SUMMARY

It appears from these results that the justification provided by the Strotz-Eisner and
Lucas papers for the geometrically declining distributed lag form of the investment function
depends critically on the assumption of fixed prices. In a dynamic world, however, it
seems more realistic to assume time dependence in economic variables. "When time
dependent prices are introduced, the investment path is no longer a geometrically declining
distributed lag and there is little evidence to indicate that an auxiliary adjustment mechanism
of any fixed form will work for all firms and at all times. Of course, it is possible to
introduce a changing K* into a distributed lag investment mechanism which is defined
so as to make the resulting path optimal. However, it would be surprising to find that
past or present levels of sales, profits, market value, or any of the other variables frequently
used as estimators of desired capital in econometric work would work very well in this
regard. The determination of the seriousness and extent of such mis-specification falls
in the realm of empirical rather than theoretical analysis, however. It is entirely possible
that auxiliary adjustment mechanisms, while possibly embodying the above sources of
error, give a sufficiently good approximation to such a broad range of underlying cost of
adjustment situations that their use is justified on the principle of Occam's Razor.

Although no simple, unique form of the investment path can be derived from the
model discussed in this paper, it is possible to establish some qualitative relationships
between investment and other economic variables which are useful in theoretical work.
Among the most important of these relationships is the finding that investment will be
increased if the path of output prices is anywhere increased and decreased if the path of
interest rates is anywhere increased.

5. INTERPRETING THE RESULTS

'The extent to which one finds the results reasonable must depend upon one's views of
how movements in the bond market are generated and also upon the method of con-
struction of the data. In this study, Grant's data have been accepted as being well con-
structed without any comment but, of course, it is possible that if data had been constructed
in some different way, slightly different conclusions would have been reached.

In this section, the more important results will be discussed in turn and possible inter-
pretations of them given.

The fact that a random walk model with no seasonal component appeared to fit the
shorter-run fluctuations of the series rather well, is to be expected from previous experience
with data from markets having an important speculative element. What is more surprising
is the clear indications that over the period analyzed, cycles with periods of two and four
years were found fairly consistently in all the series. An explanation in terms of the
structure of the market is not easily found but a possible explanation is that, possibly
coincidentally, there has been a tendency for balance of payments crises to occur in the
autumns of odd-numbered years, such as 1939, 1947, 1949, 1951, 1955, 1957 and 1961, the
only two recent exceptions being in 1956 and 1964, the latter lying outside the period
analyzed. As Government action at the times of these crises included the manipulation of
interest rates, the observed cycles could have arisen due to this periodic Government
intervention.

The close relationships found between bonds of nearly the same term is not unexpected
as it has always been considered that arbitrage by holders is usually closest between adjacent
maturities. However, the extent to which this relationship falls off with frequency has
been less clearly noted in the past. The explanation could either be phrased in terms of
investors! horizons or as being due to all the series being equally affected by Government
actions which, as they occur only fairly infrequently, can be thought of as affecting long-run
frequencies to the greatest extent. This latter explanation appears in general to be plausible,
and also fits in with the observed lead by the one-year rate over the other rates for the long-
run components as any Government action will generally affect short-term rates first and
will only slowly percolate through to the longer term rates.!

This observed lead does lend support to Meiselman's hypothesis that expectations for
bonds with longer maturities should be based on the current value of the one-year rate as
this does appear to provide a useful predictor. However, the fact that no lead was found
except for the long-run components means that his hypothesis needs to be rephrased in
terms of such components.

6. CONCLUSIONS

A number of features of the movements over time of single series and pairs of series
have been found and, in general, plausible explanations have been proposed. The results
were found to be consistent with those from other speculative markets and also with
Meiselman's form of the expectations hypothesis, when suitably amended.

It is felt that the advantage of the decomposition of the variables into several com-
ponents, which is inherent to the spectral approach, has been well brought out, as several
of the results are unlikely to have been found using other statistical methods.

CONCLUSIONS

The class of homothetic isoquant production function (HIPF) is fairly general; the
only assumption is homotheticity. This concept implies that along a ray from the origin
crossing the isoquant map all the isoquants' slopes would be equal. Any homogeneous
production function is homothetic but the reverse does not necessarily hold true.

The mathematical formulation of this function is simple and the function can be
estimated empirically on the basis of either polynomial curve fitting or numerical integra-
tion, a speedy task thanks to electronic computers. The parameters which can be estimated
are technological change, returns to scale, the elasticity of factor substitution and the
factors! shares in the product distribution.

If the data should so indicate the empirical fit of the HIPF would estimate adequately
a straight line, Cobb-Douglas, constant elasticity of substitution production function or
whatever form is relevant.

The HIPF is applicable under market conditions of differentiated competition as
well as perfect competition. Tests of the HIPF for the U.S. private non-farm economy
over the period 1929-53 give interesting results within the framework of data limitations.

course, great difficulties (both conceptual and statistical) in the construction of such an

under consideration: this is likely to be a form of misspecification. If we assume that
prices are fixed in relation to unit costs (fixed, wage and material) plus some percentage
profit mark-up, i.e. price — (unit fixed -- wage --material costs)x profit rate, then the
effect of a unit change in wage costs is seen to depend on the profit rate at the time of the
change, whilst the effect of a unit change in mark-up depends on the level of cost factors
at the time. If, as seems quite likely, percentage mark-ups remain fairly constant in the
long run but there is a marked trend in unit costs, then a given change in unit costs is
likely to produce a more or less equal change in price at all times, whereas the effect of a
given change in profit rates will vary over time and will be related to the level of total unit
costs. As the total level of unit costs will in turn be related to the existing price level, it
is seen that a given change in profit rate will produce not a given absolute, but a given
percentage change in price. Now if we assume that the level of demand is related to the
profit rate (per cent mark-up) rather than the level of profits, it follows that a given level

5. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSION

The correct specification of the labour input in the aggregate production function is
important in the study of past economic growth, in measuring the marginal product of
capital, in predicting future growth and in assessing the opportunity cost of changes in
working hours. A production model embodying separate output elasticities with respect
to men and hours has significant implications for the theory of labour supply, employment
and distribution.

Theoretical considerations suggest that the elasticity of output with respect to hours
exceeds that with respect to men. The evidence, based on Cobb-Douglas production
functions estimated for cross-sections of 24 British industries for three different years, is
compatible with this proposition. Attempts to correct for a variety of possible sources
of bias does not alter this conclusion.

Although the evidence supports the hypothesis, there is need for caution. The most
serious reservation, but one that cannot be avoided with the current data, is that a pro-
duction function estimated for a cross-industry sample may be misleading. A further
study will therefore be carried out using the United States Census of Manufactures data,
permitting intra-industry production functions to be estimated using individual states as
the units of observation. In addition, an aggregate time series study is in progress.

At this stage in the research it would seem best to assume that the elasticity of output
with respect to hours exceeds that with respect to men and is likely to exceed unity. The
traditional assumption that 5j is small or at most equal to y, may lead to substantially
incorrect predictions and policies.

The Equivalence of Liquidity Preference and
Loanable Funds Theories in Stock-Flow
Economies: A Comment

Considerable uncertainty exists over whether the presence of stock-flow goods
invalidates the Hicksian proof of the equivalence of liquidity preference and loanable funds
theories of interest. Mr Cliff Lloyd's paper [4] initiated this uncertainty by questioning
the validity of the Hicksian proof in a stock-flow economy and Baumol [1], Johnson [3]
and Shackle [7] perpetuated it by recognizing the possibility that Lloyd might be right.
This note shows that the Hicksian proof can be extended to a stock-flow economy and that
Mr Lloyd's argument failed to utilize Walras' Law for a stock-flow economy.

A stock-flow good is one which is produced, consumed, and held for future disposal
[2, 4]. The excess market demand for such a good consists of the excess flow demand
(consumption over production) plus the ''investment" demand (excess stock demand
times some adjustment coefficient). The market can be in market equilibrium or full stock
equilibrium. In market equilibrium the excess market demand is zero and stocks are rising
or falling; in full stock equilibrium the excess market demand is zero with stocks constant.
From the latter condition, Lloyd argues liquidity preference and loanable funds need not be
equivalent:

In a consistent n-good system, two of the goods being bonds and money, if any
n— Í excess demand equations are satisfied, the nth must also be satisfied, thus the nth
may be dropped . . . The loanable funds theory drops the money equation, the liquidity
preference theory drops the bond equation, but the two are equivalent . . . This is
quite a simple and clear-cut proof, provided each of the goods in the system is re-
presented by only one excess demand equation, but . . . in an explicit stock-flow theory
any stock-flow good will be represented by two excess demand equations [4].

A word of caution. Two non-negative square matrices can be as close together as

It is obvious that further disaggregation of our measurements would be valuable in

be explained by growth in input. The most important disaggregation of this type is to
estimate levels of output and input by individual industries. The statistical raw material
for disaggregation by industry is already available for stocks of labour and capital and
levels of output. However, data for relative utilization of labour and capital and for

productive factors among industries along the lines suggested by Massell [43]. The
fact that past observations do not reveal significant changes in productivity does not imply
that the existing allocation of productive resources is efficient relative to allocations that
could be brought about by policy changes. In such a study it might be useful to extend
the scope of productivity measurements to include the government sector. This would
be particularly desirable if educational investment, which is largely produced in that
sector, is to be incorporated into total output.

Finally, our results suggest a new point of departure for econometric studies of
production function at every level of aggregation. While some existing studies [29, 30]
employ data on output, labour, and capital corrected for errors of measurement along the
lines we have suggested, most estimates of production functions are based on substantial
errors of measurement. Econometric production functions are not an alternative to our
methods for measuring total factor productivity, but rather supplement these methods in a
number of important respects. Such production functions provide one means of testing
the assumptions of constant returns to scale and equality between price ratios and marginal
rates of transformation that underlie our measurement. A complete test of the hypothesis
that growth in total output may be explained by growth in total input requires the measure-
ment of input within a unified social accounting framework, the measurement of rates of
return to both human and physical capital, further disaggregation, and new econometric
studies of production functions. A start has been made on this task, but much interesting
and potentially fruitful research remains to be done.

C. Notes on the variance of the lag structures

Reasons for the variance are not difficult to find. The weaknesses of simple adaptive
expectations models have been discussed at length elsewhere and need not be restated here.
However, several problems associated with the stock adjustment model deserve a short
discussion.

Individual economic units may plan portfolio adjustments at unchanged money prices,
but for the community as a whole equilibrium real balances and actual real balances must
be reconciled through changes in the level of money prices. If prices adjust instantaneously
(in the unit period) when excess demands appear, equation (7) must describe lags arising
from the delayed adjustment of individuals. Persons may be regarded as choosing a path
that maximizes wealth (or utility) over the adjustment period, subject to the cost of adjust-
ment. When the cost of adjustment increases with the speed of adjustment, the optimum
path will be of the general form described by (7). The coefficient ó, is then a function of
the rate of discount, which for this problem is the money rate of interest; ? variance of
the lag structures may simply reflect failure to specify this dependence in a period when
there has been large variance in the money rate of interest. At the other extreme, if the
costs of adjustments are independent of the speed, persons will attempt to adjust im-
mediately. The lags implied by (7) therefore arise from lags of money prices in response
to excess demands. Unfortunately, economic theory has little to say about the form
that such adjustments should take, and the variance of the imposed lag structure may
result because (7) is not the correct form of this adjustment. A more complete analysis
would separately specify these two sources of disequilibrium.

IV. SUMMARY

The main findings of the study may be outlined topically: (1) the introduction of
second-order Pascal distributions leads to the conclusion that geometrically decaying
weight structures do not work as well as ones that peak in the second or third period;
(2) the evidence is consistent with long and variable lags,? but the demand elasticities are
not very sensitive to alternative lag patterns; (3) the demand functions are interest inelastic,
and the narrow definition of money is the luxury asset with an income elasticity of 2,
while the broad definition has an income elasticity of 1; (4) events associated with World
War II induced an increase of 20-25 per cent in the desired level of real money holdings;
and (5) the estimated equation for the broad definition of money has the smallest un-
explained variance and yields the best explanation of the rate of change of prices.

3. CONCLUSIONS GENERALES

Comme dans bien des problémes d'agrégation les résultats obtenus sont décevants
encore qu'instructifs. Pour qu'il y ait agrégation il faut qu'il y ait quasi-identité entre
les types de fonctions de production considérées. A part des différences irréductibles entre
les surfaces de base, les variations à partir de ces surfaces de base sont les mémes dans
leur ensemble pour toutes les techniques considérées, le repérage de ces variations pouvant
cependant étre différent et correspondre peut-étre physiquement à des gains (ou pertes)
relatifs doués d'un sens économique. Ces études suggéreraient donc de classer les différ-
ences entre fonctions de production en différences irréductibles et au contraire en points
communs, ces derniers étant seuls susceptibles d'agrégation.

On rejoint ainsi des idées intuitives en méme temps que l'on précise les raisons
d'examiner avec beaucoup d'esprit critique les ajustements tentés de facon empirique.

Il est aussi extrémement important de noter que les hypothéses faites sont essentielle-
ment des hypothéses de convexité (ou ce qui revient au méme de concavité). Or il est
bien certain que la recherche de progrés dans les techniques conduit, heureusement
d'ailleurs, à des rendements croissants dans une certaine zóne d'utilisation optimum,
avant que les rendements baissent au-delà de cette zóne. Dans ces conditions en admettant
une répartition physiquement optimum des ressources ce sont d'abord les techniques les
plus productives qui sont employées au moins dans certaines zónes avant que d'autres
techniques moins productives le soient. Ceci est particuliérement net avec l'emploi de
modéles de programmation linéaire.

S'il est certain que les hypothéses de cette programmation ne peuvent étre valables
dans la réalité pour des valeurs infinies des variables concernées il n'en demeure pas moins
que si les études a priori d'agrégation sont utiles pour reconnaitre le bien fondé de pro-
cédures d'ajustement ou d'analyse des données statistiques, il est aussi indispensable,
surtout aprés de tels résultats, d'étudier directement la composition (ce terme étant pris
dans un sens distinct d'agrégation qui, dans la littérature économique a fini par prendre
surtout le sens de simplification par réduction drastique des paramétres a priori considérés)
de fonctions de production (ou d'autre nature selon le cas). Le probléme le plus important
est sans doute la recherche de zónes ou bien de paliers oüà cette composition garde la
méme forme et des seuils oà des changements se produisent. La programmation linéaire
avec sa prise de conscience de fonctions linéaires par morceaux, de faces variables, etc.

. est encore un bon exemple des directions de recherche les plus utiles.

Enfin l'aspect algébrique des opérations introduites, l'importance des résultats obtenus
à moindre peine et dans des conditions trés générales sans utilisation du calcul différentiel,
mais par traduction globale des propriétés physiques ou économiques, donnent du point
de vue technique de recherche et nature du probléme de l'agrégation des indications encore
vagues, mais de toutes facons précieuses, sur l'intérét d'essayer d'unifier la structure de
nombreux problémes d'agrégation non seulement pour mieux les résoudre mais aussi
pour mieux apprécier leur consistance et juger s'ils ont un véritable intérét.

Conclusions

The results suggest that the basic model used by Brechling to account for employment
variations in manufacturing industry as a whole can be widely applied to industry groups
within the total.!

The industry results are characterized by the uniformly large labour input elasticities
that suggest increasing returns to labour in the short run in a number of cases. It appeared
that this result held even when direct labour alone was considered. It also held when
the production funcions for direct labour were estimated directly using data on measured
man hours. However such data are in principle subject to a measurement error due to the
difference between nominal and measured man hours. An attempt to take this measure-
ment error into account in estimating the production functions, resulted in sharp reductions
in a number of the labour input elasticities, which made it doubtful whether the labour
input elasticities obtained from the employment functions could be identified with the
** true " short-term production function elasticities.

The estimated elasticities from the employment functions for total labour and the
speeds of adjustment were found to be correlated with the average rates of unemployment
over the sample period. We were not able to establish the extent to which the former
correlation was due to increasing returns at high rates of unemployment, or to shifts in
the equilibrium level of productive man hours. The latter correlation is plausibly explained
in terms of greater flexibility of hiring and firing in relatively depressed industries.

I. INTRODUCTION

In a recent article [5] published in the Cahiers économiques de Bruxelles Professor J.
Waelbroeck analyzed world trade flows in a very interesting way. He took total exports
to and total imports from each region as given and applied the RAS method—-originally
constructed for input-output analysis—to analyze the extent to which flows known
from an earlier table can account for flows in a later year. The approach has some
resemblance to certain aspects of bivariate information theory. The present paper takes
this theory as a starting point to provide an alternative method of analysis. The empirical
part of the paper is based on the same data as those which are used by Waelbroeck. It
turns out that the two methods yield virtually equivalent results, which is not really
surprising, but which sheds an interesting light on the nature of the RAS method.

Section II considers international transaction shares from the standpoint of information
theory; section III considers some empirical results, and a third prediction method;
section IV the RAS method; section V, the information inaccuracy of forecasts of import
and export distributions for individual regions; and section VI traces the E.E.C. and
Communist policy effects.

THE GOLDEN RULE OF RESEARCH 145

Other theorems which could be established are that, in the present model as well as
in the model where capital in unproductive in the research sector, the rates of return to
investment in technology and to investment in the commodity sector are equal to the
rate of growth on the Golden Rule path. Proofs of these theorems would be essentially a
repetition of proofs given earlier.

Conclusions

We postulated a certain technology function which is conducive to golden ages. We
then showed that when golden-age consumption is maximal with respect to research effort,
the rate of return to '* investment in technology " equals the rate of growth. We referred
to this equalization as the Golden Rule of Research. It was also shown that when golden-
age consumption is maximized with respect to tangible investment in the commodity sector,
the rate of return from tangible investment equals the rate of growth. This is the familiar
Golden Rule of Accumulation. When golden-age consumption is maximal with respect
to both kinds of investment, the two rates of return are therefore both equal to each other
and to the rate of growth. This suggests the General Golden Rule of Investment: to
maximize golden-age consumption, assuming an interior maximum to exist, equate the rate
of return from each kind of investment to the rate of growth.

We also characterized the Golden Rule state in terms of labor allocation. It was shown
that if the labor force is homogeneous and capital is unproductive in the research sector
then exactly one half the labor force is assigned to research on the Golden Rule path. But
if capital is productive in research or if the skill at research of the marginal researcher falls
with increasing numbers of researchers, due to a nonhomogeneous skill mix, then, on
certain assumptions, less than one half of the labor force does research on the Golden
Rule path.

3. The Concept of Durability

In our above discussion of the W function, some qualifications of the durability concept
were noted. We shall now examine some further questions relating to this concept.

(i) One simplification of the durability concept lies in the certainty with which the
life span of the asset was assumed to be predictable in advance. It is more realistic to
attribute to the asset, at its birth, some probability distribution of life spans.?. 3 In such
a stochastic model of durability, the value of the asset will equal the average of the values
corresponding to different life spans, weighted by their probability of occurrence. We may
define the ** certainty equivalent " of durability as the life span which, if certain, would
result in the same value for the asset. This certainty equivalent has the interesting property
that it is decreased when the interest rate rises—as at the higher interest rate, the values of
the longer lives become relatively less important in the average. Thus the value of the
asset is more strongly affected by the interest rate in the stochastic model than in the
deterministic one. It seems to us that this will result in amplifying the effect of changes in
the interest rate on optimum durability.

(ii) Another conceptual difficulty with durability lies in the possibility of prolonging
the life span of an asset already in use. Such a possibility of rejuvenating the asset (by re-
building it, replacing parts, etc.) allows a partial postponement of the decision on durability.
In a deterministic system, of course, this question does not exist. Only when uncertainty is
present is it advantageous to postpone decisions until more information becomes available.
It seems to us that secondary (and tertiary, etc.) durability has to be introduced into
the model as an additional variable in the supply function. The solution should, therefore,
be similar, at least conceptually, to that presented here.

(iii) One should perhaps also mention two more general problems which may be of
particular importance for the durability concept. As is customarily done with economic
variables, durability was treated as continuous. It might be, however, that only a limited
number of alternative life-spans for the durable is technically possible.4 Secondly, we
have endeavored to formulate a pure theory of durability. Such an approach necessarily
disregards the possibility that in some cases extensions of durability may be technologically
inseparable from other changes in quality.

4. The Short Run, and Market Imperfections

The model presented in this paper was developed within the framework of long-run,

We should be inclined to predict that the greater is the interrelatedness of an industry,
the greater would its technological convergence be. In the 1920's, the fuel and power
industries showed higher interrelatedness than '* other iron and steel and electrical manu-
factures "' (which includes machine tools). This observation does not invalidate Rosenberg's
assertion, which relates to an earlier period (1840-1910). It does give a more precise state-
ment of the conditions which may be associated with technological convergence.

In conclusion, then, we may state that the concepts of diversification (and its converse,
specialization) and interrelatedness may be given a numerical formulation; and that input-
output data provide the basis for testing empirically a variety of assertions made about
certain tendencies in the economic history of industrializing economies. In presenting
this measure, we do not claim to have a theory in the sense of a unique prediction of the
amount of interrelatedness (or diversification) to be associated with a particular level of
development. It is nevertheless useful to have made the step of reducing to a more precise
form or number of hitherto regrettably imprecise statements about economic development
processes.

CHIOU-SHUANG YAN AND EDWARD AMES.

This paper associates with every input-output matrix an order matrix, and defines for

could, I think, best be reached by stripping the problem to its bare essentials. The main
conclusions may be summarized as follows:

(1) The total effect of a reduction of interest on prices can be split up into two com-
ponents, one of which arises from the fall in interest rates in the course of time whereas
the other is related to the lower level of interest.

(2) The first component, connected with the name of Cassel, can practically be relied
upon to work in the classical direction, but—except for possible lag phenomena—it is
limited to the time when interest rates are actually going down. It is thus essentially of a
short-term nature and gives no support to Wicksell's propositions.

(3) What Wicksell and other proponents of the classical doctrine seem to have had
in mind is rather the effect of lower levels of interest. It is not certain, however, that this
effect will work in the classical sense. As a consequence, it is quite conceivable that at
lower levels of interest prices will finally be lower than if rates had been maintained at a
higher level. This can be attributed to the fact that in the long run lower interest rates
may stimulate the expansion of capacity more than they stimulate demand.

(4) While from a theoretical point of view, these unclassical possibilities may be
somewhat disturbing and perhaps intriguing, their significance for monetary policy is
limited in several ways. First, aside from quite unlikely cases, they only apply to situations
where prices are falling to begin with; for situations of rising prices the rule of the classical
doctrine is hardly weakened. Second, even if prices are falling, unclassical reactions only
appear in the case of capital-poor economies with relatively high interest and low growth
rates. Third, if interest rates are used as a short- or medium-term instrument, the direction
of their change being reversed every few years, any unclassical reactions would tend to be
washed out in the long run and the picture would be dominated by the Cassel-effects which
are sure to work in the classical direction.

To conclude, therefore, one of the reasons why Large firms have been growing at a
faster proportional rate than Small firms during the later part of the 1950's is due to the
influence of amalgamations. This, however, is not the complete explanation as the net
assets of Large and Medium size firms gain equally from acquisitions but the former still
grow at a faster overall rate.

One possibility is that Large firms tend to be less conservative than Small firms and
revalue their assets more frequently, and so give the impression, misleading as it may be,
of faster growth. Another possible explanation is that large companies are finding it easier
to obtain money on the Stock Exchange (the Board of Trade having shown they are heavy
users), and so obtain economies of scale in finance and advantages in growth. A further
explanation could be that economies of scale in marketing and production (especially now
that technology is advancing at such a pace), are outweighing disadvantages of size. Before
any such conclusions can be drawn, however, further research needs to be undertaken.

CONCLUSIONS

It has been shown that an index of trade union pushfulness namely the rate of change
of unionisation is closely associated with the rate of change of money wage rates and that this
index cannot be explained by the level and/or the rate of change of the demand for labour.
This result is not upset in the jointly estimated model of Part 3. Our hypothesis that the
rate of change of unionisation is the index of the causal variable in the observed relationship
is therefore consistent with the data at this level of aggregation. Moreover, excess demand
as measured by the level of unemployment does not appear to have made a significant
contribution to the explanation of the variance in wage rates over the period 1921-1961.

What is now required is an analysis of the data at a lower level of aggregation. For
one thing, some of the implications of our hypothesis about the role of the union variable
can only be tested in disaggregated studies. For another, it is important to know how the
rate of change of unionisation, the level of unemployment and the rate of change of money
wage rates are related to each other in a particular sector and in all other sectors. For
example, the aggregate relationship between AW and AT' and the lack of correlation between
U and AT are consistent with either of two conflicting hypotheses. Suppose wage rates
were to rise in some sector. Let it be each union's policy to prevent any widening of inter-
industry wage differentials. Then this wage change would make unions in other sectors
more militant and, if they successfully negotiate wage adjustments, a rise in aggregate
AW and AT would be observed. Now, all this would be compatible with either an increase
in demand for labour in the sector where the wage rise originated or with an increase in
union militancy which was independent of demand conditions.

THEORY OF WAGE-PRICE PROCESS IN MODERN INDUSTRY 283

(5) The theory also throws some light on the traditional distinction between cost-push
and demand-pull inflation. Several observers have shown the difficulty of distinguishing
between these two types of inflation [21], [28], [33]. The key distinction between the two
mechanisms is not whether prices will respond to demand changes. Clearly, they respond
under either process. But under the demand mechanism, prices should be stable as long as
demand and supply remain in balance and basic costs do not change. Under the oligopoly
mechanism, prices can rise without excess demand, and the major driving force of the
inflationary process is the interaction of target-return pricing and profit-based wage
demands. While the oligopoly mechanism is likely to lead to inflationary troubles at a lower
level of demand, it may also have a stabilizing effect in periods of excess demand, when the
insensitivity of prices to excess demand will lead to a less than full exploitation of the market
position. Empirical investigation of the relative significance of the two mechanisms should
look for the response of price changes to objective measures of excess demand to sub-
stantiate the demand mechanism, and to changes in standard unit costs to substantiate the
oligopoly mechanism.

(6) The oligopoly mechanism advanced here also refutes the widely held view [33],
[28], that on the cost-push side, only wage-push can lead to a sustained inflationary process,
since only a repeated increase in business profit targets could lead to continued inflation.
It has been shown here that even a constant target rate of profit can produce a rate of
wage increase in excess of the productivity trend, and with target-return pricing, this wage
increase is passed on in higher prices, maintaining the profit rate, and also maintaining the
rate of wage increases. The oligopoly mechanism is neither a wage-push nor a profit-push
theory. It is the interaction of prices, profits and wages which maintains the inflationary
process, and it is the existence of monopoly elements in both factor and product markets
which leads to this result.

The argument of this paper refers to an occupational ladder. However, it is obvious
that there is substantial overlap between occupational levels and other aspects of social
status. Thus unskilled workers include disproportionately large numbers of negroes,
immigrants, rural-urban migrants, youths and persons with little schooling. Therefore,
variations in the skill margin reflect corresponding variations in the relative earning
position of these groups vis-a-vis those more favored, and the paradigm of the ladder has
implications for social mobility.

Identifying skill levels with social classes pre-supposes a broad consensus among
employers, paralleling the status hierarchy, as to the order of preference in selecting job
applicants. It also implies substantial correlation between educational attainment and this
order of preference. These two conditions are and long have been met in the United States
and in most other places as well. It is only in rare cases, such as Jews and Huguenots, that
one finds an inverse relation between educational attainment and position in the consensual
order of hiring preference.

The relation of age to the hiring preference hierarchy calls for a brief comment. So
far as manual workers are concerned, the young are likely to be only partially trained
and/or not yet fully committed to full-time year-round wage earning and hence more
likely to find unskilled than skilled jobs. The managerial and/or the professional ladders
are largely non-competing with the manual; but in all of them, the young largely overlap
with new entrants and as such play the role of inferior applicants relative to those previously
hired.! Hence, if there is vestibuling for these ladders, the young will tend either to slop
over into other job markets (clerical and sales) and/or temporarily retreat to school for

(i) Cross Section Studies

A number of cross section studies of the acceleration principle have been undertaken.
It is typical of cross section studies in general, and not merely of the accelerator studies,
that they yield lower correlations than time series studies. Nevertheless, the regression
and correlation coefficients that are obtained are usually significant at high levels of sig-
nificance. ?

A common procedure of the cross section studies is to fit gross fixed capital expenditure
as a proportion of gross fixed assets against percentage change in sales with a distributed
lag. Those that do not use this form still work in terms of some ratio form. The use of
the percentage change or other ratio form does have the advantage in cross section analysis
of removing heteroscedasticity as automatic adjustment is made for firm size.

The cross section studies find long distributed lags suggesting slow adjustment. lt is
interesting that accelerator effects seem to be concentrated in just those firms we should
expect—those with rising sales and more rapid growth.3

have often yielded bad results but more sophisticated models and methods have almost
invariably produced results favourable to the acceleration principle.

cause of underdevelopment. Hence estimates of the strength of structural inter-dependence
in an underdeveloped economy on the basis of data relating to existing industries tends
to be misleading. Contrafactual conditionals cannot be reflected in observational data!

tion of mutual interdependence. Thus, it would not help in explaining the absence of key
industries in underdeveloped countries.

approach itself and in particular from those concerning the interpretation of the numbers
forming the pay-off matrix.

In the commodity market, approach toward the new equilibrium will reduce the dis-
parity between actual commodity supply and that which would prevail, at any given price,
in a perfectly competitive equilibrium. The new equilibrium level of price is that at which
commodity supply will equal demand under conditions of perfect competition to all firms.
The transitory monopoly powers of the firms will have passed when prices have converged
to this new level. At the same time, elimination of downward sloping product demand
curves will have also eliminated the difference between the value of labour's marginal
product to the firm and its marginal revenue product, hence the demand curve for labour
will have returned to its original position—to Patinkin's labour demand curve. Finally,
with an unchanged labour supply curve, the real wage rate must, unless money wages are
entirely rigid, return to the original equilibrium level (w/p)o, with lower commodity prices
and a lower money wage rate, but with the same quantity of commodities and labour
demanded as in the previous equilibrium. Regardless of the initial rigidities in the money
wage rate, the force of reduced nominal marginal costs must be added sooner or later to
that of product market imperfections as a mechanism which forces commodity prices
down to the new equilibrium level.

At the end of the adjustment, then, the comparative statics result of Patinkin's analysis
has been achieved. But the use of temporary competitive imperfection as the adjustment
mechanism following a reduction in commodity demand has allowed the development of
an internally consistent system, eliminating the need both for Patinkin's distinction between
actual and desired supply and for Cross and Williamson's accumulation of unintended
inventories in perfect competition. We cannot agree with Patinkin who summarized his
unemployment model saying, ** we can see that involuntary unemployment can exist even

Conclusions

In an analysis based on the maximisation of utility we have found that the amount
of bonds compared to savings is a decisive factor in the response of saving to price level
changes. This is because the rise in prices decreases the real value of bonds and consumers
try to compensate for the loss by saving more. If the amount of bonds is many times the
amount of saving, as in the case of the United Kingdom, the increase in saving needed to
compensate for the loss in the real value of bonds is very great.

There is also an effect due to the decrease in the real value of income, but the mag-
nitude of this effect—the income elasticity of saving—probably does not vary so much
from time to time and from country to country as the ratio between bonds and savings.
In the United Kingdom the size of the income elasticity to save is small compared to the
ratio between bond and saving. Consequently the estimation of the theoretical result
showed that in the United Kingdom the effect of inflation on real consumer saving is
positive.

To see the relations between the pace of technical progress and the length of life of
plant, we must keep a clear view of what question is being put to the model. Some com-
plications (which the ingenious reader can supply) are avoided, in the comparison between
economies, by postulating that the capital/labour ratio is the same, in each economy, in
producing consumer goods as in producing capital goods, and that the degree of mech-
anisation is everywhere the same.

To exhibit the neo-neoclassical theorem, I compared two economies with the same rate
of growth and different propensities to save out of profits. In the economy where the
capitalists are more thrifty, the share of profits is less and the life of plant shorter. If we
introduce into this picture Arrow's principle of learning by doing (which means, as I inter-
pret it, that a higher ratio of gross investment to stock of capital induces a faster pace of
technical progress) then the more thrifty economy also has a higher rate of growth.

For Arrow, the ratio of gross investment to income is an independent datum. A higher
ratio (due to greater thriftiness of the economy as a whole) tends to shorten the life of
plant (by increasing the proportion replaced every year) and consequently to increase the
rate of growth.

Thus, in both models, given the propensity to learn by doing, faster growth is associated
with shorter life, but the causation runs the other way.

Now compare economies with the same thriftiness conditions, of which one has a
higher propensity than the other to learn by doing. A faster rate of growth entails a higher
ratio of investment to capital (both valued in terms of consumer goods). A given ratio of
investment to income cannot sustain a higher rate of growth unless the capital/income
ratio is lower. Thus, for Arrow, the life of plant must be longer in the faster growing
economy.! This entails that the share of gross profits on the latest plant is higher to an
extent that more than offsets the faster pace of the rise of wages. The rate of profit on
capital is thus determined.

In the Keynesian model, given the thriftiness conditions, the rate of profit is determined
directly by the rate of growth. In the extreme case where savings are equal to profits,
the rate of profit on capital is equal to the rate of growth. Now, if the capital/output
ratio is the same in the two economies, the share of net profits in proceeds is proportional
to the rate of profit on capital, which is identical with the rate of growth. On our assump-
tions, the share of gross profit is proportional to the share of net profit. Thus the two
opposing influences balance; the length of life of plant is independent of the rate of growth.

In the general case, with some consumption out of profits, the rate of profit exceeds
the rate of growth (the more so, the smaller the proportion of saving in profits). A higher
rate of growth is associated with a more than proportionately higher share of profits and
therefore a longer life of plant.

Thus in no case (on our assumptions) does a faster pace of technical progress lead
to a shorter life of plant.

Further complications can be introduced into the analysis if we allow for a choice
of technique at each stage of the learning process. A faster rate of growth tends to lead
to a lower degree of mechanisation, as well as longer life; but the degree of mechanisstion
itself reacts upon length of life, through its effect upon the share of profits in proceeds.
This was thc point that Mr Pai Panandikar was struggling to express, but at that time no
one understood the argument sufficiently to see what he was driving at.

A STOCHASTIC INCOME MODEL USING OPTIMAL INVENTORY RULES 91

Knowledge of the first two moments of our initial variables is sufficient to characterize
the time series in which these variables will be observed. Throughout, discussion has been
confined to systems that produce stable means. Thus, monotonically divergent time
series will not occur. In neither case is there a possibility of variances which converge
to zero; consequently, both models produce irregular oscillations around fixed levels.

Standard non-stochastic dynamic models generate various classes of time series: if
the roots of a second order system are complex with modulus greater than 1, for example,
the time path will diverge and oscillate. The variance of the time series composed of regu-
lar observations on this time path, will increase without bound through time. A logical
concomitant of this implication is that an unbounded variance (such as would be observed
with y — 1 in equation (10) ) is a sufficient condition for an explosive oscillatory time path.
Similarly, a stable variance is sufficient for regular oscillation with constant amplitude
(the unit modulus time path). There is, however, a much richer array of time path possi-
bilities in the stochastic models: there is no limitation to cycles with regular period and
constant (or steadily expanding) amplitude, and no dependence upon fortuitous properties
of characteristic roots to obtain realistic fluctuations. In a paper which also rejects the
standard deterministic difference equation approach in favor of a random shock mechanism
[11], Muth has shown that ** cobweb "' behaviour can be obtained without the assumption
of irrational price expectations on the part of farmers, a necessary ingredient in cobwebs
spun in the absence of random shocks.

VII CONCLUSIONS

The principal results of this study are (a) ** multiplier-accelerator '" mechanisms can be
modified to accommodate random shocks; the modified mechanism generates series which
afford a better representation of observable series than do the more familiar non-stochastic
difference equation models. (b) The rules for inventory investment prescribed for retailers
in the new normative literature of managerial economics contain characteristics which
may lead to substantial amplification in the inherent variability of the system; so long as
the smoothing motive remains attractive to the manufacturer, however, this amplification
may in part be offset before it is transmitted to the employment and output decision level.
(c) Under all conditions that can be foreseen in models which relate consumption to
current income, systems are stable, i.e., the variance of the income variable converges to
some finite level.

Chicago. DANIEL ORR.
